SourceProxy.name: Slam (Online)
SourceProxy.label: Slam (Online)

Documentation.short_help: Performs SLAM algorithm on the Lidar sensor's point cloud
Documentation.long_help: Performs SLAM algorithm on the Lidar sensor's point cloud. The SLAM algorithm is composed of three sequential steps: - Sampling strategy: extract keypoints that provide strong geometric information - Ego Motion: Sensor motion estimation between two frames - Mapping: Map the frame in an environment map

SourceProxy.Documentation: Filter which performs slam on pointcloud data

IntVectorProperty.name: Display Mode
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If display mode is enabled, some extra arrays are added to the output to display some of the SLAM algorithm internal variables (the keypoints labels, the value of the computed geometric features, ...). It is very useful when debugging and improving the SLAM

IntVectorProperty.name: Verbosity Level

Entry.text: 0) Errors, warnings or one time info

IntVectorProperty.name: Fast Slam
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If fast slam is enabled, we don't use blob keypoints

IntVectorProperty.name: Ego-Motion registration
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: If enabled, Ego-Motion step will be perfomed by globally registering current frame on previous one. Otherwise, Ego-Motion is estimated using previous motion extrapolation.

IntVectorProperty.name: Undistortion Mode
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Undistortion mode, to correct rolling shutter distortion during a whole sweep during Lidar frame acquisition. This might be slower and unstable in case of jumps. If DISABLED, SLAM will compute a rigid transform that will be applied to the whole frame without taking into account the distortion due to the lidar motion during a sweep. If APPROXIMATED, current beginning sweep pose will be guessed using a constant speed motion model from previous and current end sweep poses. Then, linear undistortion between current begin and end poses is applied. If OPTIMIZED, both current begin and end sweep poses are optimized. Then, linear undistortion between current begin and end poses is applied.

IntVectorProperty.name: Number of threads
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Max number of threads to use for parallel processing.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Translation
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Position of the LiDAR sensor in BASE coordinate system (X, Y, Z). It is often useful to track a BASE pose instead of LiDAR sensor pose. If set, this parameter transform all input pointcloud into BASE coordinate system in order to output BASE trajectory.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Rotation
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Rotation of the LiDAR sensor in BASE coordinate system (rX, rY, rZ, euler angles in ZYX convention, in degrees). It is often useful to track a BASE pose instead of LiDAR sensor pose. If set, this parameter transform all input pointcloud into BASE coordinate system in order to output BASE trajectory.

IntVectorProperty.name: Lev-Mardt Maximum Iteration
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: The sensor motion estimation is performed using an ICP Mahalanobis distance function. This lead to a numerical optimization problem with a non-linear least square cost function (with a loss-function). To solve this optimization problem we use the Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm which is an iterative algorithm.

IntVectorProperty.name: ICP Maximum Iteration
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: The sensor motion estimation is performed using an ICP Mahalanobis distance function. The ICP algorithm is an iterative algorithm and the number of iteration has to be set

IntVectorProperty.name: # Edges Neighbors Minimum After Ransac
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: In the Ego-Motion step, the neighborhood of an edge keypoint is fitted using a ransac algorithm. This parameter sets the minimum number of inliers we want to keep currently considered point

IntVectorProperty.name: # Edge Neighbors
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: K-nearest neighbors points to consider to compute the Variance-Covariance matrix of the neighborhood to define the Mahalanobis distance function.

IntVectorProperty.name: # Plane Neighbors
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: K-nearest neighbors points to consider to compute the Variance-Covariance matrix of the neighborhood to define the Mahalanobis distance function.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Linearity Factor #1
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Reject an edge keypoint if its neighborhood is not distributed along a line eigenvalue1 > Factor * eigenvalue2

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Planarity Factor #1
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Reject a planar keypoint if its neighborhood is not distributed along a plane: Factor1 * eigenvalue2 > eigenvalue1 and eigenvalue2 > Factor2 * eigenvalue3

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Planarity Factor #2
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Reject a planar keypoint if its neighborhood is not distributed along a plane: Factor1 * eigenvalue2 > eigenvalue1 and eigenvalue2 > Factor2 * eigenvalue3

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Max Edge-Neighbors Distance To Fitted Line
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Reject an edge point if its neighborhood has points that are too far from the fitted line (degenerated ellipsoid)

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Max Plane-Neighbors Distance To Fitted Plane
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Reject a planar point if its neighborhood has points that are too far from the fitted plane (degenerated ellipsoid)

PropertyGroup.label: Ego-Motion ICP Matching And Optimization Parameters

Property.name: Max Edge-Neighbors Distance To Fitted Line
Max Plane-Neighbors Distance To Fitted Plane

IntVectorProperty.name: Lev-Mardt Maximum Iteration M
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: The sensor motion estimation is performed using an ICP Mahalanobis distance function. This lead to a numerical optimization problem with a non-linear least square cost function (with a loss-function). To solve this optimization problem we use the Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm which is an iterative algorithm.

IntVectorProperty.name: ICP Maximum Iteration M
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: The sensor motion estimation is performed using an ICP Mahalanobis distance function. The ICP algorithm is an iterative algorithm and the number of iteration has to be set

IntVectorProperty.name: # Edges Neighbors Minimum After Ransac M
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: In the Mapping step, the neighborhood of an edge keypoint is fitted using a ransac algorithm. This parameter sets the minimum number of inliers we want to keep currently considered point

IntVectorProperty.name: # Edge Neighbors M
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: K-nearest neighbors points to consider to compute the Variance-Covariance matrix of the neighborhood to define the Mahalanobis distance function.

IntVectorProperty.name: # Plane Neighbors M
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: K-nearest neighbors points to consider to compute the Variance-Covariance matrix of the neighborhood to define the Mahalanobis distance function.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Linearity Factor #1 M
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Reject an edge keypoint if its neighborhood is not distributed along a line eigenvalue1 > Factor * eigenvalue2

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Planarity Factor #1 M
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Reject a planar keypoint if its neighborhood is not distributed along a plane: Factor1 * eigenvalue2 > eigenvalue1 and eigenvalue2 > Factor2 * eigenvalue3

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Planarity Factor #2 M
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Reject a planar keypoint if its neighborhood is not distributed along a plane: Factor1 * eigenvalue2 > eigenvalue1 and eigenvalue2 > Factor2 * eigenvalue3

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Maximum Inlier Distance Ransac Line Fitting
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Reject an edge point if its neighborhood has points that are too far from the fitted line (degenerated ellipsoid)

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Max Edge-Neighbors Distance To Fitted Line M
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Reject an edge point if its neighborhood has points that are too far from the fitted line (degenerated ellipsoid)

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Max Plane-Neighbors Distance To Fitted Plane M
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Reject a planar point if its neighborhood has points that are too far from the fitted plane (degenerated ellipsoid)

PropertyGroup.label: Mapping ICP Matching And Optimization Parameters

Property.name: # Edges Neighbors Minimum After Ransac M
Maximum Inlier Distance Ransac Line Fitting
Max Edge-Neighbors Distance To Fitted Line M
Max Plane-Neighbors Distance To Fitted Plane M

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Map Edges Voxel Grid Leaf Size
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Size of the leaf when downsampling the environment map using a voxel grid filter. It should not be too big or some high frequency geometric information will be lost. It should not be too low or the geometric information will be too local

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Map Planes Voxel Grid Leaf Size
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Size of the leaf when downsampling the environment map using a voxel grid filter. It should not be too big or some high frequency geometric information will be lost. It should not be too low or the geometric information will be too local

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Map Blobs Voxel Grid Leaf Size
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Size of the leaf when downsampling the environment map using a voxel grid filter. It should not be too big or some high frequency geometric information will be lost. It should not be too low or the geometric information will be too local

IntVectorProperty.name: Map Voxel Grid Size
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Size of the map used to store the keypoints (number of voxels in each direction). The map needs to have a size sufficient to store at least one frame.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Map Voxel Grid Resolution
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Resolution of the map (meters per voxel). It should not be too big or too much points will be considered when trying to match the frame at the current position. This do not impact accuracy but only speed.

Property.name: Map Edges Voxel Grid Leaf Size
Map Planes Voxel Grid Leaf Size
Map Blobs Voxel Grid Leaf Size

SourceProxy.name: Slam (Offline)
SourceProxy.label: Slam (Offline)

Documentation.short_help: Performs SLAM algorithm on the Lidar sensor's point cloud
Documentation.long_help: Performs SLAM algorithm on the Lidar sensor's point cloud. The SLAM algorithm is composed of three sequential steps: - Sampling strategy: extract keypoints that provide strong geometric information - Ego Motion: Sensor motion estimation between two frames - Mapping: Map the frame in a environment map

SourceProxy.Documentation: Filter which performs slam on point cloud data.

IntVectorProperty.name: All Frames
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Process all frames

IntVectorProperty.name: First Frame
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Set the first frame to process

IntVectorProperty.name: Last Frame
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Set the last frame to process

IntVectorProperty.name: StepSize
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Process one frame every StepSize frames (example: every (1) frame, every 2 frames, every 3 frames, and so on). A StepSize of 1 (the default value) means that all frames between the first and the last (included) will be used. This property can be useful to trade robustness (StepSize equal to 1) and accuracy for speed (StepSize bigger than 1).

IntVectorProperty.name: Neighbor Width
IntVectorProperty.Documentation: Number of neighbors on both sides of current point used to estimate the keypoints scores (curvature, angles, depth gap, ...) in each scan line

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Minimum Distance To Sensor
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Minimum distance (in meters) between a point and the sensor to be processed for the keypoint extraction. In other words, all points too close from the sensor are automatically rejected.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Maximum Sinus To Be Considered As Planar
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: One strategy to consider a point as a planar keypoint is to compute the angle between the two lines that fit its previous and next neighborhoods. If the angle is close enough to 0° or 180° (sin(Angle) low enough), we consider the point as a planar keypoint.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Minimum Sinus To Be Considered As Edge
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: One strategy to consider a point as an edge keypoint is to compute the angle between the two lines that fit its previous and next neighborhoods. If the angle is close enough to 90° (sin(Angle) high enough), we consider the point as an edge keypoint.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Minimum Saliency Distance To Be Considered As Edge
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: One strategy to consider a point as an edge keypoint is to compute the depth gap between the point and its far background neighborhhod. If the gap is big enough, we consider the point as an edge keypoint.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Minimum Intensity Gap To Be Considered As Edge
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: One strategy to consider a point as an edge keypoint is to compute the intensity gap between the point and its left and right neighbors. If the gap is big enough, we consider the point as an edge keypoint.

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Minimum Depth Gap To Be Considered As Edge
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: One strategy to consider a point as an edge keypoint is to compute the gap between the point and its neighborhood. Its left and right neighborhoods are fitted with a line and then we compute the gap as being the distance between the point and the fitted lines. If the gap is big enough, we consider the point as an edge keypoint

DoubleVectorProperty.name: Angle Resolution Between Two Firings
DoubleVectorProperty.Documentation: Azimutal angle resolution of the Lidar sensor (radians). This angle resolution is used to compute an expected distance between two consecutives firings. From this expected distance, we can detect if a point is a potential gap and launch more investigation

Property.name: Maximum Sinus To Be Considered As Planar
Minimum Sinus To Be Considered As Edge
Minimum Saliency Distance To Be Considered As Edge
Minimum Intensity Gap To Be Considered As Edge
Minimum Depth Gap To Be Considered As Edge
